moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 Bf5 3. Nf3 Nd7 4. h3 h6: Interesting, well known but not much played, for a reason.
moves.8. gxf5 exf5 9. h4: or Rg1 at once. It is intended to prevent g5.
moves.9... Ngf6: This deprives white's queen of the h5 square. Avoiding g5 had this price.
moves.10. Rg1: Freeing my knight from the pin, and eyeing g7.
moves.10... Ng4 11. Bh3: This black pieces are less dangerous then it seems, and I keep on threatening things. Now, of course, black has the edge, and after h5 clamps me very badly... but so does himself. It would be another game.
moves.11... Bd6: This black bishop is one of my best pieces, but true is that actually it is not doing much.
moves.12. Bxd6 cxd6: A doubled central pawn, maybe not good for me.
moves.13. Bxg4: ...but now I can cash my pawn. Too bad I lose my second bishop.
moves.13... fxg4 14. Rxg4 Qf6: I want to jump with the knight with a plan, not just taking it off there.
moves.15. Rf4 Qg6 16. Rc1: I mantain it was better than NxB. Qg1+ looks ugly.
moves.16... O-O-O: This gives me an idea. But I saw it late, after I moved...
moves.17. Ke2: I thought that after Qg1 I would have ran out of the pressure. THis kind of strange defence can work, sometimes, but I overlooked the obvious...
moves.17... Rdf8: No choice. h5, Qxh5, Rh4 doesn't look appealing.
moves.20. Nxf3 Qg4: I saw this, and my defence is...
moves.21. cxd5+ Kb8 22. Qh1: Ugly, but it somehow stops the inmediate threats. Now black has to find a way to break in.
moves.22... Nf6 23. Rg1 Qh5 24. Rxg7 Nxd5: This knight, in this square, is well far from threatening mine, so...
moves.25. Rd7: I started a ball, here, shocked that I wasn't mated yet.
moves.25... Nf6 26. Rxd6 Ne4: Not even this worries me... can it be possible?
moves.27. Re6 Qg4 28. Rxh6: My defence holds, against all odds, and my rook is free to fly here and there.
moves.29. Kxd2 Rxf3: A mate is in sight for white, but, very, very surprisingly...
moves.30. Qh2+: White wins (or gets an overwhelming advantage).
moves.31. Rh8+: What's the game? It will be back and forth.
moves.31... Kd7 32. Rh7+: ...and here, white has drawn game, since black can't affort to move the king away from squares d7 or c8, or it will be mated. Don't believe me?
moves.32... Kc6: If Ke6, Qe5#. If K in the 8 row, other than c8, Qb8#.
moves.33. Qc7+ Kb5 34. Qxb7+ Kc4 35. b3#: Poor black. It was hard to foresee!
